body: Still Making Deals At a Different Table Years back, Theodore W. Kheel helped settle so many big and bitter labor disputes in New York and around the country that he was widely regarded as the maestro of mediation. These days, he still uses his talent for bringing people together, though for ends other than soothing passions at the bargaining table.
title: FOLLOWING UP

body: IN a cluttered and paint-splattered studio in Dumbo, the Brooklyn neighborhood where he spends most nights working, Scott Chester is designing a motorcycle for Spider-Man. Not the Spider-Man who climbs bridges to fight the Green Goblin, but the one who fortifies city structures against terrorist attacks for the New York City Department of
title: DRIVING; Couture Motorcycles

body: It is called the Empire Stores, and for more than 50 years the cavernous, forbidding warehouse has been abandoned, a magnificent ruin between the Brooklyn and Manhattan Bridges along the East River. A signature of the Brooklyn skyline for at least 130 years that has transfixed residents and, to an extent, defined the waterfront, it has nonetheless
title: In Dumbo, Remaking a White Elephant; Brooklyn Waterfront Landmark, Long Abandoned, Awaits New Life

author: E-mail: amh@nytimes.com
body: CHARLOTTE DEWALD had grown fond of the tree outside her Greenwich Village window, even though she didn't know what kind it was. Then one fall day, she looked out the window in silent greeting, only to discover that every leaf had been plucked off. A film crew, shooting ''The Out-of-Towners,'' with Goldie Hawn, had stripped the tree, apparently to
title: COPING; Cameras Love Neighborhoods. The Feeling's Rarely Mutual.

body: WHETHER you are shopping for gifts or sprucing up your home for guests, five new stores in New York can help with the holidays. Among their wares are Chinese antiques and first-apartment furniture, as well as 25,000 square feet of storage solutions, some previously available only through Web sites, catalogs or in suburban malls. This season, they
title: PERSONAL SHOPPER; Try It, Buy It, Store It or Display It

body: Stella Harmatiuk, 81, stood on the corner of Manhattan Avenue and Calyer Street in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, on a recent windy morning and smiled beatifically at the people walking down the sidewalk. Until they got close. Then she snapped into candidate mode and accosted them with a pink flier bearing her likeness. ''Hold it!'' she barked. Many obeyed.
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: GREENPOINT -- CITYPEOPLE; Finding No Shortage Of Windmills To Tilt At

body: ''I don't like to be in the center of everything,'' said Patrick Eck, 42, a cabinetmaker. ''And I need a lot of space.'' He has found both solitude and space in the South Bronx. Last month, Mr. Eck and his companion, Marketa Psenickova, left, finished renovating their 3,000-square-foot loft in a former vinegar distillery (the white building,
title: CURRENTS: HABITATS; In the South Bronx, Peace and Quiet in a Loft of One's Own

body: FreshDirect can deliver more than 3,000 grocery items to your doorstep, according to its Web site, sparing New Yorkers ''both the lines and the schlep'' to the supermarket. But Upper West Side residents are finding that convenience comes at an unadvertised price: idling trucks. ''It's a mini-distribution center on every corner,'' said Cleopatra
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER WEST SIDE; Food Direct to the Door; Noisy Trucks, Too

body: As the conversion of old industrial buildings to residential use continues and new apartment buildings rise in the Dumbo area of Brooklyn, the number of developers active in the neighborhood has also been increasing. One of the more active in Dumbo, or Down Under the Manhattan Bridge Overpass, is Boymelgreen Developers of Brooklyn. The company,
title: Residential Real Estate; More Builders Are Joining In Development of Dumbo

body: Where pigeons once nested and squatters roamed free there are now designer furnishings and expensively buffed walls. Windows that once rested askew in a cracked brick façade now hang straight, while rotting floors once punctured by industrial chutes have been replaced by blond wood. It was a little more than six months ago that Bob Vila shot the
title: This Old Factory, Refurbished by Bob Vila and Others

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE; For the Brownstone Set, Two Glossies Make a Pitch

body: Construction is still under way on Bridgefront, a 10-story condominium at 42 Main Street in the Dumbo area of Brooklyn, but 18 of its 21 loft-style apartments have been sold in the two months since sales began. title: POSTINGS: Bridgefront in Brooklyn; Condos Selling In Dumbo

author: Vivian Gornick is the author of ''FierceAttachments,'' a memoir about growingup in the Bronx, and most recently, '''The Situation and the Story: The Art of Personal Narrative,'' published by Farrar Straus & Giroux.
body: THE other day I took a walk through Chinatown with Jami Gong, listening to his assured young voice tell me he was going to take me on an ''insider'' tour -- born and raised here, he knows the neighborhood inside out, these are his streets -- starting at a corner on the eastern edge (Canal and Eldridge), moving steadily along Division Street,
title: NEW YORK HEARD; And Don't Worry About the Tip

body: He wears a gray beard and tight dreadlocks, a golf shirt and short pants, all of it rumpled and soiled as if he just arose from bed or never slept at all. The telephone in his apartment rings every three minutes or so, and hardly a postage stamp's worth of flat surface is clear. Life's minor miracle for the day is that Danny Simmons is able to
title: Art Galleries as a Brooklyn Bridge

body: JORDAN Zielin grew up in Fort Greene, Brooklyn. But in late 2000, he landed his dream job as a computer systems engineer for Banc of America Securities, and moved to Boston. In the back of his mind, he planned to return to New York someday. His timetable suddenly accelerated after Sept. 11, 2001. His first job after college had been as a research
title: COPING; Downtown, Fine Feelings Fall Victim To the Banal

body: AS far as anyone knows, no vinegar has ever been mass-produced in Vinegar Hill, a minuscule neighborhood covering only eight blocks close to the Manhattan Bridge anchorage and abutting the Brooklyn Navy Yard on the borough's northwestern shore. In fact, its name comes from the site in County Wexford, Ireland, where Irish rebels fought the English
title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Vinegar Hill, Brooklyn; On Cobblestone Streets, History Lingers

body: The Cypress Hills National Cemetery in Brooklyn is the final resting place of several long-dead luminaries, among them a few Medal of Honor winners and a Fiji cannibal chief named Vendovi, who was said to have eaten up to a dozen American sailors before his capture. But undoubtedly the cemetery's oddest historical attraction can be found off by
title: TUNNEL VISION; He Was Custer's Bugler. Then, the Subway Called.

body: It would probably win any competition for laundry with the best view. And that is only part of what 360 Furman Street, a behemoth 12-story building on the Brooklyn Heights waterfront, has been used for in the past 20 years. The 961,000-square-foot building, owned by the Jehovah's Witnesses, is also a distribution center for religious literature.

body: UNLESS you make an enemy of him, or front him a bushel of money for a real estate adventure, odds are that David C. Walentas, the developer who latched onto Brooklyn's derelict Dumbo neighborhood decades ago and, several hundred million dollars in equity later, sees himself as its mayor, won't remember your name. Don't await an apology. It's deals,
title: PUBLIC LIVES; One Name He Can Remember. It Was an Elephant's.

body: Like the Kremlin, to which Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg compared it yesterday, 110 Livingston Street was more than a location or a shorthand name for the institution it housed, the city's Board of Education. It symbolized a state of mind, a failed system that was at once imperious and impervious. Rudolph W. Giuliani famously called for it to be
title: So Long, School Bureaucrats: 110 Livingston Is Being Sold

body: Opponents of New York City's longstanding cabaret laws, some dressed in fishnet stockings and ostrich plumes, spoke at a forum about the laws yesterday evening, carrying signs with slogans like ''The Waltz is Illegal in New York City.'' The six-hour hearing at New York Law School was attended by about 190 people, most critical of the laws. It began
title: At a Hearing, Ostrich Plumes And Pleas for Freer Cabarets

body: JOEL HOWARD and Tracy Tucker, both 40, are partners, co-workers and Texans. They come from proud Suburban-driving, central-air-loving families, from houses with big yards and bigger garages. Their move to New York three months ago, Mr. Tucker said, was as extreme a culture shock as you can have without learning a new language. Six months or so
title: Habitats/Brooklyn; For Two Texans, Dumbo Isn't a White Elephant

title: CURRENTS: DESIGN SHOWS; Introducing New Faces and Talent From Brooklyn

body: While the industrial buildings of Dumbo have become increasingly trendy in recent years, there is one place the neighborhood's artists can be assured that the bejeweled and Botoxed won't follow their lead, and that's up a grimy abandoned elevator shaft in search of some exercise. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DUMBO; A Little Like Everest, Only Greasy And Illegal

body: Over nearly two decades, Jane Walentas has toiled -- reading and learning, scraping and chipping, recording and cataloging -- to return a historic carousel to its past splendor. Mrs. Walentas and her husband, the developer David Walentas, paid $385,000 for the rare carved-wood merry-go-round at an auction in 1984 and decided that, once restored, it
title: Hold Your Painted Horses; Rare Carousel Awaits a Spot in Brooklyn, if Politics Allows

body: HERE'S this little railroad on the Brooklyn waterfront with 1.5 miles of track, one locomotive and a three-man crew -- the engineer, the conductor and the brakeman. Trains like speed, but this one never goes faster than five miles an hour, on rails that run through Sunset Park, beneath the arched footbridges of the Brooklyn Army Terminal, and
title: Riding the Bounding Rails

body: Like many of his neighbors, Michael Crane, president of the Dumbo Neighborhood Association, does not want to see the Gap come to his neighborhood. Mr. Crane is not talking about the clothing store but rather a blocklong dead space that could be created if a residence hall for the Jehovah's Witnesses goes up at 85 Jay Street. The Watchtower Bible
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DUMBO/BROOKLYN; Paving a Parking Lot and Putting Up Paradise

body: John Yung has long heard stories about a neighborhood of art galleries that sits nestled under the Manhattan Bridge overpass along the Brooklyn waterfront. He often watches the industrial buildings glow at night as he walks home from his job as a waiter in Chinatown. But Mr. Yung, who is 27 and lives near East Broadway, has never crossed the bridge
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DUMBO/MANHATTAN; In Unlikely Urban Shadows, A Shopping Haven Takes Root

author: Ross B. Intelisano is a lawyer.
body: Beginning today, New Yorkers must dial 1, plus the area code, plus the seven-digit telephone number, to complete any local telephone call made within or between New York City boroughs. That's 11 digits in total, whether the call is from Manhattan to Manhattan or Brooklyn to Queens. The Federal Communications Commission says this change will
title: Ending the 212 Clique

body: AS NEW YORK confronts momentous questions -- about the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan, its budget woes, the danger of terrorism, the prospect of the Olympics in 2012 -- there is no shortage of predictions on where the city is headed in the next few decades. To peer into the future, the City section has consulted a dozen historians, sociologists,
title: New York's Tomorrow: 12 Visions

body: In 1774, a Yale University student named David Bushnell invented the first wooden submarine, called the Turtle. It was 7 3/5frac12 4/5 feet long and 8 feet tall, just large enough to hold one man with air for 30 minutes, and it was operated by foot pedals and hand levers. Its mission was to affix 160-pound bombs to blow up the British ships that
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DUMBO; If You Know How to Rig a Sloop, Raise Your Hand and Get Aboard
